name: Rolando Pujol
bio: Welcome to The Retrologist, telling stories from the classic American roadside! 📸  ✍️ Like my Instagram? Please subscribe to my newsletter!👇

social_posts.post_text:
This time of year was the Sears time of year. I can remember the cheery commercials from the 1980s, promising a shopping experience that equated Sears with Santa himself.

The jingle went, “There’s more for your life at Sears,” and that was more than a slogan — it was a promise. 

You named it, Sears had it, like the ones shown here, in Hackensack, New Jersey (first three photos) and Flatbush, Brooklyn (final two photos). Both closed forever. 

Even then Sears still mailed out its Wish Books, with thin, glossy sheets that had a particular smell that was redolent of yuletide promise. (I loved the Spiegel catalog, too, for similar reasons.)

As far as I was concerned, those Wish Books might as well have been printed by Santa’s elves in the North Pole, and circling what I wanted in the tantalizing toy section was like telegraphing my wishes directly to Jolly Old Saint Nick himself.

The collapse of Sears has been astonishing, once unthinkable, but slow enough that we’ve had time to accept it. There are only 15 stores left, where not long ago there were thousands.

Will Christmas 2022 be the last Christmas we have Sears? I explore the question (and much more, by the way) in my latest newsletter, at the link in my bio. Please take a second to subscribe! #retrologist

Hi friends! In my latest newsletter, I'm making it a Blockbuster weekend. There's a Blockbuster Video pop-up bar in Los Angeles that's making news, and, down in Florida, a bar that plays on Blockbuster nostalgia. I have details on both in The Retrologist newsletter, at link in bio, but for my money, it doesn’t get better than the real thing, and that’s the Last Blockbuster in Bend, Oregon, which I visited in May 2021.

The first five photos are from that store, and the rest are of an abandoned one I stumbled upon in Ashland, Kentucky, back in June.

Also in the newsletter, I visit one of the last McMansards in NYC and share headlines about an iconic California sign that's making a big comeback next week.

To play on the Blockbuster theme, please "be kind" and subscribe! Link is in my bio and also in my stories. 🙂#retrologist

The White Plains Mall was a dead mall for a long time, but it lingered on its deathbed for decades. 

I last visited — I should say, paid my respects — back in January 2019. Some of the mom-and-pop shops were somehow hanging on, the DMV — the mall’s anchor at this point — was still there, and this McDonald’s — which might have been the last in business to use the “Town House” branding — was the liveliest place here on the cold afternoon I stopped by. 

Almost four years later, this mall in White Plains, New York, is all gone — including those abstract 1970s tree designs I loved so much, which I’ve included in my gallery.

On Thursday, ground will break for a big new housing development here, the first phase of which will cost $350 million. 

And the future of more dead malls may well be homes for the living. 

Please visit the link in my bio to read my full newsletter on this mall, plus a tour of the ghosts of Toy “R” Us, the story of the new 50-foot-tall “Christmas Story” lamp and more intriguing tales from the American roadside. And while you’re there, don’t forget to subscribe! #retrologist

Hello! My latest newsletter is out (subscribe at the link in my bio) and I’ve got a heaping helping of roadside news to share.

I say goodbye to Bischoff’s, a beloved New Jersey ice-cream parlor that is closing after 88 years.

Plus, I visit the The Neon Museum of Philadelphia, which is sadly closing on Sunday. (Buster Brown and Howard Johnson’s Lamplighter Room pics are from there!)

I share the story of the rise and fall of the McDonald’s mansard as news breaks of another one being McBoxed in Virginia.

Plus, I have an update about the “dead” White Plains Mall and news about Ponderosa (good) and Sizzler (not so good).

Please make sure to sign up for my newsletter if you enjoy my Instagram, and thanks! #retrologist

In my latest newsletter (easily subscribe at the link in the bio) I share the sad news that one of the nicest old-school Krispy Kreme stores left in America has closed, apparently for good.

The Savannah, Georgia, location on Skidaway Road, which dates to 1968, is finished, customers were informed in signs left on the windows on Monday. 

These are my photos from my visit in 2019, about which I observed: “There are only a handful of Krispy Kremes of this 1960s design still in business, and this one right before you is one of the sweetest.”

How bittersweet it is. #retrologist

Hey you guys! The “Goonies” house in Astoria, Oregon, has been sold to a superfan! This city is a must visit for fans of the 1985 movie! Here’s a quick tour, and visit the link in my bio for more “Goonies” sites and other retro spots in and around Astoria, all in my latest newsletter! #retrologist

Hello from the road! I’m filing this from Florence, South Carolina, as I explore the Southeast in a pre-Christmas adventure. If I’d been traveling, let’s say, back in the 1970s, the orange roof of a Howard Johnson’s off in the distance or the “Great Sign” of a Holiday Inn were signs of safe harbor for the weary traveler -- a good meal and a good night’s rest awaited right beyond the exit.

In my latest newsletter (find at link in bio), I share a link to the @the_eps_podcast in which I discussed the legacy of HoJo’s and Holiday Inn with host Eric Paul. It’s a fun listen! Please visit the newsletter and give the show a listen!

In my latest newsletter, I also have some good news about neon signs out west, including a pink elephant, and an update on Lucy the Elephant, whom you might say is in the pink! Those are among over a dozen roadside Americana headlines, so please check it out! #retrologist

Greetings from Santa Claus, Georgia! I had the good fortune (and timing) of stopping by here a few days ago, and oh by gosh, by jingle, I was taken by the “Southern home” of Kris Kringle.

This city – population about 200, if you don’t count Santa and his helpers – was incorporated in 1941, the brainchild of a pecan farmer who wanted to sell more pecans, so he figured calling it Santa Claus might do just that. The farmer, Calvin Greene, even served as its first mayor, but World War II hit this city like Santa’s sleigh running into fog on Christmas Eve, with no Rudolph to guide this town out of trouble. A grinchy reporter from the Associated Press put it thusly about this city’s difficult first years. “A charter was granted. Came the war. No gas, no tires, and now no Santa.”

Ouch.

But Santa is all about faith, and Farmer Greene kept believing.

And so in the 1960s, the town’s second mayor, developer Bill Salem, turned out to be a true believer, too. He picked up the farmer’s Santa bag, and filled it with gifts. Salem turned this place into the tidy little city you see today, which has homes sitting on streets with names like Noel, Candy Cane and Dancer; a community center; a chapel and garden; and even a gas station and convenience store named after jolly St. Nick.

Got Christmas cards? You can drop them in the Believe mailbox and they’ll get a special Santa Claus, Georgia, stamp on them! You can stop in at City Hall, located at 25 December Drive, of course, or check out the museum and gift shop across the street to find something special for the nice folks on your list.

Yes, Virginia – well, Georgia in this case – there is a Santa Claus! #retrologist

My latest newsletter is out (link in bio!), and I’ve got some Christmas treats for everyone! On my road trip through the South this past week, I visited so many interesting places, including some of the spots here. They include one of just three remaining Suncoast Videos in the nation, an old Spencer’s with the late 1990s look, the Hills of Snow snowball stand, the iconic @claxton_fruitcake bakery, which is near Santa Claus, Georgia, a great @stuckeystop mural and more. Plus, I take you to the homes from “Home Alone,” “A Christmas Story” and “National Lampoon’s Christmas Vacation.” All in the newsletter -- please give it a read and subscribe to get them emailed right to you. #retrologist

The other day, I shared some of my photos of the relics of chain stores that are defunct (or almost there). That inspired me to put together this video featuring photos of 21 stores that are no more, or are far from what they once were.

Read my latest newsletter (link in bio) for locations of these places and much more news from the American roadside! 

Which places do you miss? Which would you add to a future video? #retrologist

As we wrap up 2022, I’m looking back on the year and my adventures on the road. My most popular post of the year here on Instagram marked the 82nd birthday of @dairyqueen. Today, as a sweet way to end the year, I put together this Dairy Queen Reel featuring my photos!

To learn more about these locations, please visit the link in my bio to read my latest newsletter. And tomorrow, I’ll share a video with my other top photos of the year.

Thanks so much for your support this year, for following me here and for sharing your passion for these places and knowledge with the community we’ve built together. The best way to support my work is to subscribe to my newsletter, which you can do at the link in the bio!

Happy New Year’s, friends!🍦🥂 #retrologist

Happy New Year! Thanks so much for making 2022 such a memorable year for me on Instagram! Your continued support here, and now on my newsletter, which I invite you to follow at the link in the bio, is deeply appreciated.

I’ve got big plans for 2023, but before I start on all that, I took a breather today and looked back at my top 25 posts of 2002, as measured by the number of Instagram accounts reached.

Here’s a little video I put together, starting with No. 25. It was fun to revisit these posts. I hope you enjoy this stroll down memory lane.

25: Eli’s Orange World, Kissimmee, Florida
24: Arby’s, Cudahy, Wisconsi
23: Wonder Bread Lofts, Columbus, Ohio
22: Dairy Queen, Roseville, Minnesota
21: Roast Grill, Raleigh, North Carolina
20: Former A&P, Clinton, New Jersey
19: Kewpee Burgers, Lima, Ohio
18: Pizza Land, North Arlington, New Jersey
17: Yogi Bear Fried Chicken, Hartsville, South Carolina
16: Former Bakery Thrift Shop, Cleveland, Ohio
15: Former Ames, Horseheads, New York
14: Pizza Hut Classic, Bryson City, North Carolina
13: Gibeau Orange Julep, Montreal, Canada
12: Pink Motel, Cherokee, North Carolina
11: Chips Restaurant, Hawthorne, California
10: Former Longaberger headquarters, Newark, Ohio
9: Malley’s Chocolates, Cleveland, Ohio

7: McDonalds’s, Tomah, Wisconsin
6: In-N-Out original store replica, Baldwin Park, California
5: Lexington Candy Shop, New York, New York

In my latest newsletter, which you can subscribe to at the link in my bio, I share news about the demolition of a classic @arbys that dated to the 1960s in Richmond, Virginia. But the sign has been spared at least.

As I write in the newsletter, "the style of this building — rolled out around 1976 — was the immediate successor to the original chuckwagon design dating to the chain’s launch in 1964. The fact that the restroom was accessible from outside, in the back of the building, was another clue that this was originally a chuckwagon-style building." Thanks to my friend and former Tribune Broadcasting colleague @scott_wise of @cbs6 for the update on the demolition and the aftermath shots. 

Plus, only in my newsletter, I have what is expected to happen next to the sign; news on McDonald's leaving the New York State Thruway; a throwback Burger King closing in Washington D.C.; and over a dozen more headlines from the retro American roadside. Please sign up and never miss out! #retrologist

Last year, I brought you the news that one of the best-preserved old-school McDonald’s in America was about to be demolished.

As I wrote then, “We’ll see how this looks when it’s done. I hope they preserve the sign, and maybe keep a few of the characters for old-time’s sake. But it will never be the same.”

Well, that’s more or less what happened.

This McDonald’s, in Milford, Connecticut, had since been replaced with a smaller building, swapping out the 1972 mansard for the 2022 box, and eliminating what had been billed as New England’s largest McDonald’s PlayPlace altogether.

All that remains of the original complex is the “Big M” sign, which dates to when this McDonald’s first opened in 1966, and, in the lobby, a statue of Ronald McDonald relaxing on a bench.

All the other traces of the McDonaldland era, which you can see in the video, are gone.

I’ve got more vintage photos of this McDonald’s, plus a lot more roadside Americana news, in my latest newsletter, which you can sign up for easily at the link in my bio. #retrologist

On Sunday, January 10, 1999, 24 years ago tonight, “The Sopranos” debuted on HBO, and the landmarks of New Jersey it featured quickly became stars in their own right.

As has become an annual tradition, I’m sharing some of my favorite pictures I’ve taken of places connected to the show. The exact locations, and map link if you wan to visit, are in my newsletter at the link in the bio.

Here are the spots I profile in my Reel:

1.) Pizza Land, North Arlington, New Jersey
2.) Holsten’s, Bloomfield, New Jersey
3.) Centanni’s, Elizabeth, New Jersey
4.) Wilson’s Carpet, Jersey City
5.) Satin Dolls, Lodi, New Jersey

Tonight commences my second annual binge of the show, and what better episode than the one that aired 24 years ago this evening. #retrologist

Blink and you’ll miss it. I photographed this right before the blink. This is one of my favorite photos, mainly because it shows such a rare thing – the sign for this long-defunct bagel shop in Dyker Heights, Brooklyn. In September 2014, I was tipped off to its emergence, and made it down here just in time. It was gone a few days later, either removed or entombed again by the successor business.

This is not the first National Bagel Day in which I’ve shared this sign, and it probably won’t be the last, because as I reviewed my photos of bagel places, this one alway rises to the top!

What’s not to love here? Just savor the flames, the holes where the neon tubing once existed. As I wrote a while back, “it’s comforting if frustrating to realize that there is a veritable museum of New York retail history hiding under new signs and cheap vinyl awnings all around town. And every so often, this clandestine museum offers a surprise exhibit. It’s free, but you have to act fast. Or it might just disappear again, this time forever.”

For a treat, check out my latest newsletter (link in bio) to watch a short documentary film from the 1970s called, appropriately enough, “Hot Bagels.” It will help explain the world from which this sign came. #retrologist

They all hurt, but this one hurts more than most. Dutch Haven in Lancaster County, the heart of Pennsylvania’s Amish Country, has closed and is on the market for $2.4 million.

During my first visit 25 years ago, Dutch Haven in Ronks made one heck of an impression on me. It was the sort of place that helped set me on the storytelling path I’m on today.

How could Dutch Haven not invite curiosity and compel a pullover? The yellow building with its massive rooftop windmill is the stuff of roadside dreams, and to step inside is to be transported to another time. There is the shoofly pie, made from an old recipe, and the free samples that immediately sold me on the Pennsylvania Dutch treat. I enjoyed it every time I visited.

Inside were charming and eclectic regional souvenirs, Amish furniture, and more. The decor was a throwback, too. And there were hex signs, lots of them. Hex signs, variously described as tools to ward off evil, attract good fortune and undeniably add beauty, are a Pennsylvania Dutch barn tradition that I first learned about at Dutch Haven. I own a couple of them — created by Jacob Zook’s company — and they each came from Dutch Haven.

A buyer who wants to keep this place going would be purchasing a turnkey operation, as Stahl left everything — from the merchandise to the recipes — in place. (See the listing in my newsletter, link in bio.)

Wouldn’t it be nice if a buyer came along who was turnkey — not bulldozer — minded? All this space — 3.5 acres on which sit several buildings — makes the land rather appealing for somebody looking to start something new, not involving shoofly pie or Hex signs or T-shirts that say “I love Intercourse.” (Intercourse is a Pennsylvania community that is part of what I like to call the Pennsylvania Sexual-Repression Belt, with names like Virginville, Blue Ball, Climax, Bird-in-Hand and Mount Joy. It’s enough to make a Retrologist blush.)

But back to Dutch Haven. What will become of it and those cheeky souvenirs?

I have the full story and many more roadside reports and photos at the link in my bio in the latest edition of my newsletter! Consider it a “haven” in your inbox! #retrologist

Wendy’s sunroom.

Those two words pack a lot of nostalgic punch.

Along with Wendy’s newspaper tables and salad bars, the sunroom holds a special place in the firmament of fast-food restaurant history. If a restaurant was getting built or renovated from the mid 1970s through the early 1990s, there’s a good chance a sunroom was getting glued onto it. 

Wendy’s made an art of it.

The other day, a picture of a Wendy’s sunroom went viral, the poster asking if such things were a thing anymore. Multiple people tagged me, figuring I knew the answer. The short answer is yes, they are still a thing, but they are less a thing every day, as Wendy’s of a certain vintage fall victim to the glass-box craze, for which I suspect nobody will be nostalgic in the 2050s.

The other day, I drove past a nice example of Wendy’s sunroom in the hamlet of Vails Gate, New York, in Orange County. I pulled over for these photos at sunset, because you never know just when the sun will set on a Wendy’s sunroom.

At this point, I will switch to proper Wendy’s terminology for the sunroom, and that is greenhouse. This is how they were described in old newspaper ads in the 1980s.

They were greenhouses not simply because they let the sunshine in, but because they were full of plants!

Let’s revel in the wording from a 1983 ad for a Wendy’s that had just been “sunroomed.”

“The addition, which fronts the restaurant, will increase seating by 22 customers who will be able to enjoy the mouth watering delights at Wendy’s in an atmosphere of lush green plants.”

The ad goes on from there, telling us that the foliage – “the cluster of hanging vines” – is not the “only thing growing at Wendy’s. So is the menu.”

And you better believe this growth extended to the salad bar, with the addition of the ultimate in 1980s self-service food luxury: Jello parfait and breadsticks!

Of the “Greenhouse Wendy’s” I’ve visited in recent years, none have plants, and the salad bars have been pretty free of green, too.

Follow my newsletter – link in bio – for more Wendy’s coverage. And, coming soon to the newsletter, a tour of the Wendy’s museum complete with newspaper tables! #retrologist

One of the good guys of the great American road has died. Good guy doesn’t quite cut it. Hero is more like it.

I never had the honor of meeting Albert Okura, but people who love roadside Americana, who are preservationists at heart, owe Mr. Okura a debt of gratitude. If you’re reading this, that probably includes you.

Ever been to the ghost town of Amboy, California, a Route 66 icon along with its recently restored sign for Roy’s Motel and Cafe? Mr. Okura BOUGHT this little desert town in 2005 for $425,000. He was trying to preserve a special place along the American road. He had the means to do it, and so he did it.

Okura had the means because of his great entrepreneurial knack in the restaurant business.

His own hero was Ray Kroc, the longtime CEO of McDonald’s who turned an innovative and successful San Bernardino hamburger stand built by the brothers Dick and Maurice McDonald into a global behemoth.

That first McDonald’s was where Kroc, hawking Multimix milkshake machines, met the brothers and bought into their business in the early 1950s. Okura took a page from Kroc’s manual of entrepreneurship and built up his own restaurant success story -- the @juanpollo rotisserie chicken chain, after working in the fast-food business for years.

The first Juan Pollo opened in 1984 — there are now 26 in Southern California. Okura envisioned a chain that would spread far beyond its Inland Empire base.

He funneled some of his wealth into buying the site of that original McDonald’s in 1998 and turned it into an unofficial museum for the Golden Arches, which I had the pleasure of visiting in 2013, just off Okura’s beloved Route 66.

Through these photos, you get a sense of Mr. Okura’s contributions to preserving American roadside traditions, from the early days of fast food in the cradle of its birth in California, to a neon-bathed ghost town along Route 66.

Mr. Okura died last week. He told Salon once:

“If it’s something you want, it’s true. Believe it.”

Okura may have been inspired by Kroc, but it’s hard not to be inspired by Okura.

More photos and history in my newsletter at the link in the bio. And thank you @pake50 for the photos of Mr. Okura. #retrologist

Punxsutawney Phil has spoken and the forecast is grim: six more weeks of winter. Given that this winter has been more like spring, at least where I live in New York, the meteorologically minded groundhog’s forecast isn’t particularly threatening.

But heck, this tradition, brought by German immigrants to Pennsylvania centuries ago and made all the more popular by a certain Bill Murray movie released 30 years ago, is the light-hearted escapism America needs right now. And if you want to plan a trip that’s really lightheartedly escapist, may I recommend a visit to Phil’s hometown, where this furry fellow is a very big deal indeed.

A bowling alley. A car wash. A family restaurant. A bar (well, a “burrow” in local parlance.) You name it, Phil has left his mark on this town. There are Phil statues all around the place, too, sponsored by local businesses. My favorite, given my love of quirky fast-food locales, is Phil dressed as Wendy Thomas, the namesake of the Wendy’s hamburger chain. It’s right across the street from Groundhog Plaza, where you can shop for essentials and Phil souvenirs at the local supermarket, the Shop’n Save. (While at this plaza, check out a really old Dollar General sign, too.)

I also visited the burrow where he spends the rest of the year, as well as Gobbler’s Knob, the place where thousands gather in the chilly February dawn to witness the official weather prognostication.

It was a madhouse today but a serene affair on the splendid autumn afternoon when I visited last October. That’s when I recommend visiting, but if you love crowds, you know when to go. Either way, I forecast you will have fun. #retrologist

Happy Sunday! It’s always a thrill when my photos inspire art. So I was so happy to see these two works created by @homefront_design. First up is White Manna Hamburgers in Hackensack, New Jersey, followed by the beloved Pizza Land in North Arlington, New Jersey, featured in the opening of “The Sopranos,” which I’m binging yet again. 

In other news today, my latest newsletter is out! You can read it at the link in the bio, or visit my story for the link. I’ve got a lot of news on diners — some on the market, others in new hands; an update on the former Nabisco cookie factory that’s about to crumble; news from the L.L. Bean factory store in Freeport, Maine (you’ve got to see the big Bean Boot!); and much more. If you enjoy my Instagram, I think you’ll love my newsletter. Thanks as always for your support! #retrologist

Architectural Digest is lovin’ this McDonald’s. The magazine declared it one of the most beautiful McDonald’s in the world.

In my latest newsletter – find it and sign up at the link in my bio – I take you inside the Fort Dells McDonald’s at Wisconsin Dells, and share its fascinating history, with roots in Disney’s Frontierland, the Fort Dells amusement park that was inspired by it, and the woodsy, watery wonderland that is Wisconsin Dells. (How I love it!)

As I write in my newsletter, “Despite its architectural rigidity, McDonald’s has allowed quirky designs to flourish among the sea of mansards and now McBoxes, special locations that are synchronized with their host communities.”

This is the story of one of them, the start of a series looking at quirky McDonald’s in my Retrologist newsletter. Please sign up and follow along!  #retrologist

Happy National Pizza Day!

A reminder on this special holiday that you can read my Retrologist’s Guide to Pizza Hut Classic locations at the link in the bio.

Since I first published this article, based on painstaking research, back in October, I’ve added over a dozen locations, with over 60 now on the list!

If you like my Instagram, I think you’ll feel the same about my newsletter.

It’s easy to sign up – just subscribe at the link in my bio, or in my story! 

These restaurants are so much fun – as Pizza Hut’s co-founder, Dan Carney, explains on plaques at these retro locations: “Pizza Hut Classic celebrates our heritage with a design that’s reminiscent of our original dine-in restaurants.”

They really are a time capsule! Please let me know if you end up checking out any of these @pizzahut locations! #retrologist

Lenny’s Pizza had made it to a huge milestone — 70 years.

If 1953 was an important year for Lenny’s, the most significant in its history came 24 years later — 1977. It was during that year, in which New York saw the rise of Studio 54, the capture of the Son of Sam and the saga of the 1977 Blackout, that Lenny’s Pizza enjoyed a cameo in “Saturday Night Fever,” and the rest, as they say, is history.

And, now, 2023 will the saddest year in Lenny’s history, because it will be its last.

@its_josephinegiordano, daughter of longtime owner, Frank, announced on Friday that the pizzeria is closing. Her dad decided to retire, and Lenny’s will go with him. Doors close Sunday at 10 p.m. Expect long lines.

I have much more in my newsletter, at the link in the bio. Please sign up if you enjoy my Instagram — and wonderful slices of New York like Lenny’s. #retrologist

It’s not every day I get to share good news like this: The Arthur Treacher’s restaurant in Garfield Heights, Ohio, has reopened, two years after shuttering amid the pandemic.

This is big news, as it takes the number of existing Arthur Treacher’s standalone restaurants from, well, just one to now a whopping two.

Details at this time are scant, but @clevelanddotcom confirms that the restaurant is back in business, and “just in time for Lenten season.”

The other remaining standalone Arthur Treacher’s is in Cuyahoga Falls, Ohio, which I visited last summer.

Up in my newsletter – link in bio – I have more details as well as photos, as well as much more news from the American roadside. If you like my Instagram, you’ll love my newsletter. Please give it a read and sign up! #retrologist

In New York City, where I live, there hasn’t been enough snow this wretchedly warm winter to make a snowman or even a “Snoboy.”

But at least I can remember my visit last year to Minneapolis, where I finally photographed the iconic Snoboy sign! Snoboy is something of an orphaned sign – his parent company left town long ago –  but he’s hardly abandoned and is very much loved. 

In fact,  you may well have enjoyed Snowboy fresh produce – “picked for flavor,” as the old slogan goes – without even realizing it.

In my latest newsletter, up at the link in my bio, I tell you all about Snoboy, and where you can find this sign if you want to visit it yourself. Plus, I have 14 more headlines from the American roadside, including the closure of a 130-year-old cheese shop in New York’s Little Italy, and the threats facing an Art Moderne motel along the Lincoln Highway in Pennsylvania. Please support my work by signing up for The Retrologist newsletter! #retrologist

My latest Retrologist newsletter is out — find it at the link in my bio and sign up — and it’s full of vintage goodness! Among the stories I have for you: the owner of the reopened Arthur Treacher’s Fish and Chips Restaurant in Garfield Heights, Ohio, is looking to expand the chain; NYC’s Subway Inn opens again in what is now its third home in 86 years; and a beloved “spiedies” restaurant in New York’s Southern Tier closes. (And yes, I explain what a spiedie is.)

Plus, I have an update from Wildwood, sad news from the Lincoln Highway, a cool Lego model inspired by a Montreal landmark, a “Gold Medal” ghost and its real-life inspiration and many more headlines I hope you’ll enjoy if you follow me here. Please subscribe and never miss a beat! #retrologist

With its stepped-gabled roofline that seems more Flemish than Florida, its candy-cane poles supporting the simple portico, and its gigantic neon sign featuring a chicken and a chick that has a proto “Partridge Family” vibe, Maryland Fried Chicken has long been a cinematic stop along the strip-mall sameness of Colonial Drive — the old Highway 50 — in Winter Garden, Florida, just outside Orlando.

The fried-chicken fans who flock here no doubt take comfort in the architecture, but they are really here for the comfort food from one of the last outposts of a chain that could have been a contender and almost was a contender but has still managed to survive in pockets of the Southeast — and, in a small city in Michigan.

So to me, that makes Maryland Fried Chicken a plucky survivor.

Until April 1, when it closes for good.

Up in my newsletter, at the link in the bio, you can read the story of this location and of Maryland Fried Chicken, which was founded in Orlando, not Maryland (there’s a fun backstory). What’s more, in my newsletter, I’ve also written a second post with a guide to surviving locations, plus more photos. 

Subscribe and support my work! #retrologist

My latest newsletter is out – link in bio – and it’s jam-packed with roadside Americana news. I discuss the closure of the iconic Neil’s Coffee Shop on Manhatan’s Upper East Side and share photos from my last visit there. What will become of this place? I then head to Florida, with troubling news of a fire at the beloved “Big Orange” in Kissimmee, but they hope to reopen soon. Plus, a neon supermarket sign is being restored in Manhattan, and up in Hyde Park, New York, you have a chance to run your very own drive-in theater – owned by the National Park Service! Plus, Dutch Haven is back in the news, and I have over a dozen more stories in the newsletter, including the closure of River View East, a sacred stop on any New Jersey hot dog tour. Please subscribe and support my work! #retrologist

Where’s the beef?

That wasn’t always a slogan for Wendy’s around here. From 1945 to 1977, the site of this Wendy’s in Sunnyside, Queens, was home to the Sunnyside Garden Arena, where the beefs were between boxers, wrestlers and rolly derby players at the magnificently dingy, neon-bedecked arena that stood here, at 45th Street and Queens Boulevard.

When it was demolished in December 1977, the plan was to build a Wendy’s once the tatters of the temple to the sweet science were carted away.

The Wendy’s, 45 years later, still stands. The building has been updated a tad – the original was likely yellow, lacking a mansard roof and that 1980s sunroom – but otherwise, fast-food time has slowed here. The sign touting “old-fashioned hamburgers” survives, too, attracting motorists, pedestrians and straphangers rumbling above on the No. 7 train. Wendy’s has been selling burgers here much longer that punches were ever traded at the arena.

Most who stop by likely have no idea what Sunnyside Garden Arena was, much less that it was built in the 1920s by the grandson of industrialist Jay Gould, for more genteel pursuits like tennis. They might think you are referring to the Lewis Mumford-approved pioneering garden-home community nearby, Sunnyside Gardens, not the pugilistic ancestor to their local Wendy’s. But since 2012, a monument on the front lawn has reminded us of those other beefs of yore. 

It reads in part:

“This monument is in honor and dedicated to those men who fought in the amateurs and professional bouts.”

It was placed here by Ring 8, a group that advocates for veterans of boxing — “boxers helping boxers,” as they say. 

And there’s more than sports and fast food history on display here. There’s politics – John F. Kennedy stood here while running for president in 1960. And there’s television – the Dumont network broadcast matches from here in the medium’s earliest days, a medium that lethally deprived local boxing arenas of their audiences. 

It goes to show you that wherever you go, there’s more than meets the eye. And when you realize that, it can feel like a punch in the gut. #retrologist

On August 6, 1980, an estimated 150,000 people jammed into the Galleria mall in White Plains, New York, just north of New York City. It was the opening day of an 865,000-square-foot behemoth in the heart of downtown: an enclosed mall encased in a Brutalist concrete bunker spanning 10 acres and two immense city blocks, even bridging a major thoroughfare.

The Galleria opened with pomp, circumstance, and clowns mingling with eager crowds, quickly captured the zeitgeist of 1980s pop culture, and is now closing with a whimper, kind of just fading away.

Yes, it’s another mall closure in an era when news of dying and dead malls is commonplace, just as ribbon cuttings at mall grand openings were routine a generation earlier, but this one hits different, as they say, because the Galleria was My Mall, and I loved it.

I said farewell to the Galleria recently in a visit with @yazcountry. We both spent a lot of our youth roaming its Italian marble halls, shopping, socializing, hanging out in the food court.

Today, the Galleria, which was once home to 150 shops and two anchor department stores, is down to just one store – a hobby shop on the ground floor that used to be a Sam Goody. (Swipe to see a relic.) And it will clear out of there by Friday, March 31, which according to reports is the last day of the Galleria.

Up in my story, click the link to my newsletter, where I explain why the Galleria was built, what it was like, why it’s closing and what might replace it. Remember to sign up for my newsletter, too, the best way to keep up with my work.

Did you ever shop at the Galleria? What are your mall memories? #retrologist

On Saturday, on a jaunt to Long Branch, New Jersey, to photograph a recently uncovered early 20th-century Coca-Cola mural (post coming soon!) I stumbled upon this untouched mansard McDonald’s.

This is not your usual McDonald’s, I’d like to point out, at least what passes for usual these days. Aside from having escaped (for now) architectural sterilization, the location has an interesting history.

This McDonald’s, at 925 Route 35 in Middletown, New Jersey, was the 157th store in the chain and the fifth in New Jersey, having opened on Sept. 15, 1960. (See my newsletter in the link in bio to see how it looked then!) On that day, local resident Billy Hayer became the first person here to bite into a burger, according to newspaper archives. The introduction of the Filet-O-Fish here, in early 1965, just in time for Lent, was headline news. (The menu in 1960 was simple: hamburgers, cheeseburgers, fries, shakes, soda, coffee, milk, root beer and orangeade.)

This building here is likely the second on the site, having replaced the original “red-and-white” walk-up McDonald’s, which featured “neon-lighted rainbow arches.” The small building had a 400-square-foot kitchen, enclosed in a 900-square-foot perimeter of quarter-inch plate glass, allowing customers to ensure the “preparation of his food is quick and clean,” the Daily Record reported in 1960.

Today, it’s a shrine to the proprietor’s love of golf and a relic of the way McDonald’s looked everywhere until not that long ago. Read much more about it – and learn about the loss of a historic McDonald’s sign in Illinois, at least from public view – in my newsletter at the link in the bio. #retrologist

When Arby’s opened at 400 Knollwood St. in Winston-Salem, North Carolina, in 1968, it was a big deal. The chain of fast-food restaurants, specializing in roast beef rather than burgers or fried chicken, was only 4 years old but had already spread far from its birthplace of Boardman, Ohio.

The “10-gallon hat,” festooned with neon, fanciful typography and dazzling incandescent lighting, was quickly becoming a symbol of the American roadside, a grand example of look-at-me-and-pull-over-and-spend-your-money-now American vernacular of the highest order.

In an article published on Dec. 8, 1968, the Winston-Salem Journal described the Arby’s as the “biggest traffic-generator” at the new Knollwood Shopping Center, and when I visited on Memorial Day in 2021, the Arby’s, pandemic and all, was still lassoing them in.

Well, my fellow nostalgic cowpokes, it’s time to grab our dusty hats and place them solemnly across our chests, because the Arby’s at 400 Knollwood is no more.

This was the last 10-gallon hat sign left at an original Arby’s in North Carolina, following the destruction (desecration really) of the one that was taken down on Hillsborough Street in Raleigh last year.

I have much more, including photos, a vintage ad and more Arby’s coverage in my newsletter, which you can read (and subscribe to easily) at the link in my bio. #retrologist

There’s something special about a Friday night at a @pizzahut Classic — catching up with friends while making new ones! 

This is the first location I found in my travels that has been “retro renovated” into a Classic, in Tunkhannock, Pennsylvania, bringing back stylistic cues from the chain’s heyday. Back in May 2020, it was closed for sitdown service but tonight, it was like a Pizza Hut Friday of yore — families, friends, kids, red cups, salad bars! 

Since my first visit, I’ve put together a definitive (and still growing) list of PH Classics, which you can find at the link in my bio. I love that the bill has the famous 1980s Pizza Hut slogan, “Makin’ It Great.” One does not usually smile when getting the bill!

The meal was pretty good, and everything hits better at a Classic. The company at the table was even better, and that’s what it’s all about, after all. 

The joint was pretty busy, too. I snagged a few shots when tables were freed up, giving the impression we had the place to ourselves. 

Nostalgia means business, and Pizza Hut gets it. 

Have a great weekend, all! #retrologist

I just got back from a two-day trip through Pennsylvania and finally explored Johnstown, which has long been on my list. Johnstown is one of those places you just know about -- if anything, because of the epic floods this community has coped with over the years.

George’s Song Shop has survived many of the floods since, and has had to move around as a result since its founding in 1932. It’s been at its current home at 128 Market St. since the late 1970s, and the charming counter by the front door proves that Disco-era vintage. Crammed within the shop are millions of albums, a staggering collection of music, along with what I call patina and possibilities -- so many possibilities.

Overwhelmed, I didn’t even know where to start. It was much easier to pick up my camera and snap. This place is a sight to behold. I strongly recommend, if you collect vinyl, as I do, to come armed with your wish list and with time to spare, because chances are, the object of your desire is in here, somewhere. Owner John George is the most expert of guides.

It turns out my visit was well-timed, coming one day before Record Store Day, which is today.

In recent years, LPs have overtaken CDs in sales, a trend George is seeing, too, though the decline in CD sales and the jump in vinyl sales comes out a wash on the bottom line, he told me.

George’s Song Shop bills itself as the oldest record shop in the country, a claim contested by Rinehart’s Music and Video, in Kirksville, Missouri, which says it’s been selling records since 1897. (The oldest in the world is Spillers Records in Cardiff, Wales, founded in 1894.) There’s a shop near me in New Jersey, Music Country, that opened in 1934, and appears to be the oldest in the New York metropolitan area. (I’m due for a visit there soon.)

But no research rabbit holes await me on this mellow Saturday afternoon. I’ll just enjoy the photos of this wonderful shop, be thankful it’s still there and be grateful that Mr. George has kept this place going all those years, running it since he was 19, when his father died back in 1962.

That’s long play, all right. #retrologist

Well, I’ll be! Hardee’s without the Carl’s Jr. star!

I photographed this billboard not in the late 20th century but just last week!

I was traveling through Breezewood, Pennsylvania, a quirky traveler’s oasis where multiple highways converge. Some knock it as a tacky tourist trap – and a traffic trap on big getaway days like Thanksgiving’s eve. But to me, it’s a thirst trap – a sensational slice of roadside Americana, at the intersection of kitsch and convenience.

I love stopping in the souvenir shacks and snapping photos of the towering signage – and the relics of seedy old motels on the fringes. Bring a good telephoto lens to take some epic shots of American highway culture.

But there was no time for any of that on this last trip. I had places to go, and Breezewood wasn’t on the itinerary this time.

I hopped off the Lincoln Highway and onto the access road to the Pennsylvania Turnpike, immediately regretting not remaining on U.S 30 and basking in Breezewood’s bounty.

But a surprise – an archaeological find, of sorts – awaited just around the corner.

As I approached the Turnpike, I noticed this vintage billboard for Hardee’s. I couldn’t believe it. I looked behind me and saw no cars, so I grabbed my camera, fired off the shutter and shuffled off before I could get rear-ended. 😅 

The sign features the logo used from 1976 to 1999. It touts Hardee’s breakfast and fried chicken, and likely dates to the early to mid 1990s, even if the design feels very 1970s/1980s. Hardee’s purchased Roy Rogers in 1990 and began to sell that chain’s fried chicken. In 1997, Hardee’s got lassoed by Carl’s Jr., and soon, the logo was changed and Carl’s Happy Star was smiling from Hardee’s signs.

The billboard seems to be painted or pressed onto the base, hiding in plain sight, presumably for decades.

The @hardees in town sadly burned down last year. It’s still listed as open, however, so perhaps they are back in business.

This find is another reminder of why I love Breezewood – part travel oasis, part time travel. 

I visited dozens of vintage places on my Pennsylania trip. Please visit the link in my bio and subscribe to my newsletter to see what I found! #retrologist

We all have “My” restaurants. You know, “My” McDonald’s. “My” Taco Bell. “My” Wendy’s.

You may not eat there very often or at all. You may be so calorie and cholesterol conscious that you wouldn’t be caught dead in one, for fear of ending up that way. “Your” restaurant may simply serve as a handy landmark when giving directions.

But these places are still yours, mine and ours. Part of the landscape of life in the neighborhoods, byways and highways of America.

At some point over the past few days, “My” Burger King in Jackson Heights, Queens, closed. It had been there since at least 1976, the earliest reference I could find in New York newspaper archives, a vintage that is evident from the building’s design. The 1980s photo from the NYC Municipal Archives shows the same building was there, though the shingles were once rust.

I stopped here from time to time, for the occasional treat after a long day, usually an Impossible Whopper, which made me feel a little better about said indulgence.

My highway exit is right next to this Burger King, and you could always inhale the flame-broiled goodness before hitting the road.

Usually, when a longtime franchise closes, there’s a note in the window saying goodbye, or explaining that a renovation is under way. No such note here. A neighborhood Facebook group has talk of a Chick-fil-A taking roost here.

The Dumpster out back was a sad sight, topped with a bag full of the colorful flags that always festooned the place. The signage seems  to have been carted off site.

Across the street, there is still an old-school “sunroom” Wendy’s, and the site of these two near each other gave a time-warp feel to this stretch of Northern.

Last year, an iconic White Castle closed down the road. A vintage IHOP kicked the bucket a few years before that. And long before that, this stretch of Northern lost an Arby’s.

These all had vintage buildings, and I loved the interior design of the Burger King. 

I’ve shared more photos of it, along with much more nostalgia road-trip news, in my newsletter, just published and waiting for you to read (and sign up!) at the link in the bio. #retrologist

Peter Parker of Forest Hills, Queens, has a Burger King near him in the neighborhood of Rego Park. But he’ll have to travel a little farther, to Astoria, Queens, where he can really “Have It His Way.”

That Burger King has been transformed into a web-slinging immersive attraction tied to the release June 2 of the next film in the Spider-Man franchise, “Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse.”

The fries, they taste the same at the McDonald’s in Lewiston, Idaho, just like they do at any other McDonald’s, even with the state’s proud reputation for potato cultivation. The burgers, they taste the same, too. As do the McNuggets, the shakes and the pies, and just about everything else on the menu.

The menu is standardized, sure, but everything else here isn’t, and that’s why I think this McDonald’s is one of the coolest ones you can visit in America.

You might think that this restaurant is very old, from the 1950s or 1960s, somehow forgotten. But it was actually built in 2001, and replaced a 1970s mansard-roofed building that was once the standard model for the chain.

Twenty years ago, or what’s otherwise known as an eternity ago,  McDonald’s was building retro locations that played off the heritage of the building style that preceded the mansards. The design was rooted in the chain’s 1950s adolescence, buildings that were vanquished for the traditional-looking mansards starting in the late 1960s. 

As much as we are nostalgic today for those brown and red roofs of the mansards, back in the 1990s and 2000s, there was nostalgia for the older buildings, with the twin golden arches flanking the buildings known as the red and whites, for the colors of their tile. Quite a number of these were built, and I still run into them, though their exuberance has been tempered by gray and black colors, and their interiors updated. 

Not so at this one in Lewiston. This one remains special, and one of the most special features here is its sign, which plays off the look of the sign at the oldest-operating McDonald’s, in Downey, California, whose sign itself is unique.

The Lewiston McDonald’s opened a week before Christmas in 2001, and is still a gift for those of us looking for a taste of roadside character.

"It's a throwback and it's new and futuristic,” the owner told the Lewiston Tribune back in 2001. 

It’s still “Happy Days” here, right down to the poster in the dining room from the old sitcom that was always a throwback, just like this restaurant. #retrologist

On Memorial Day weekend in 1934, Thomas Carvelas was 28 years old but had already racked up a lifetime of living. At the age of 4, he emigrated from Greece to Manhattan’s Lower East Side, his big family (three brothers and three sisters) among the legions trying to find their way in America. The young Carvelas had already tried out a few careers, among them Dixieland band drummer and auto mechanic in New York City. He had a head for machinery, too, which would come in handy later for reasons I will soon explain.

His life took a fateful turn when a doctor in 1932 delivered troubling news: Carvelas had tuberculosis — a dark spot on his lung seemed to prove it — and he’d be wise to get out of the city. He didn’t go far physically, but in every other regard, an epic journey was about to begin.

Westchester County, just to the north of the city, beckoned, promising a restorative elixir of fresh air and nature. (No strip malls and office parks yet!) The doctor, it turned out, got it wrong — Carvelas did not have TB, but no matter, he’d find his life’s calling in Westchester: iconic ice cream man with an Anglicized last name, Carvel.

There were no Carvel stores in the early days — just a truck he’d bought with a $15 loan from his wife, which he would joke he never repaid. That truck broke down on Memorial Day weekend 89 years ago, a flat tire marooning him across from a pottery store at 95 South Central Ave. in Hartsdale, New York, according to the company origin story. 

Carvel said he was on his way to a county fair when the breakdown happened, but he made a sale before he could figure out what to do. Customers didn’t mind the melty ice cream, and they kept coming. He stayed put for the weekend, hooking up his truck to a power outlet at the pottery shop, he said in 1976, and cleared $100, a pretty good haul in the middle of the Great Depression.

Soft ice cream, huh? OK, soft serve it is. Fate had served him a big idea.

I invite you to read the full story, see more photos and videos, and explore my guide to classic @carvelicecream stores in my Retrologist newsletter, at the link in the bio or in my story. #retrologist

On Saturday, as some pals and I took a drive in search of roadside gems in New Jersey, I paid a visit to this cute-as-a-button Dairy Queen on Route 10 in Randolph. It still features the classic ellipse logo – it’s been likened to “lips” – that was developed in 1958, the work of the firm Lippincott & Margulies, in whose sure hands fast-food chains like Taco Bell and Pizza Hut have entrusted their brands over the decades. According to DQ’s book celebrating its 75th anniversary, the red stands for warmth and food, moving away from the original cool-evoking blue, and reflective of the chain’s introduction of hot food. The shape of the logo was meant to evoke “leaves and freshness,” or even a diamond, representing quality. Some see a representation of DQ’s red spoon. I just see beauty, charm, and love. That ellipse might as well be a heart as far as I’m concerned. ❤️ 

The logo cost a mere $25,000 to develop. It survives in updated form in the new logo, rolled out in 2007, which has been slowly but surely erasing the 1958 original from the landscape, but not everywhere.

I love that this beauty is still here, still focused on the simple pleasures of ice cream on a warm sunny day. (I’ll be writing soon about the sad closure of the Dairy Queen in Carbondale, Illinois, which featured an even older version of this logo on its neon sign, in a dispute over the store’s direction with corporate. That sign will be lit one final time Wednesday night.)

I certainly hope that in the vastness of DQ’s empire – there are over 4,000 in the United States –  that there continues to be room for special, small, roadside DQs like the one in Randolph. Please support them, and make sure @dairyqueen knows how much they mean to you. They are indispensable parts of roadside Americana.

Want to see more photos and an itinerary of over a dozen nostalgic places to visit in New Jersey? Head up to the link in my bio, sign up for my newsletter, and start planning your road trip! #retrologist

The first Friday in June is designated as National Donut Day. 🍩 🎉 A box of donuts usually carries a dozen, but I couldn't help myself. I’ve got 10 sweet retro locations here, and 14 more in my newsletter, for two dozen! See it at the link in my bio, along with location information for each one. 

Enjoy, and drop a comment with your favorite donut place! #retrologist

This is really one of the nicest-looking McDonald’s around from the mansard era, which began in 1968 and ended in the mid-2000s.

This one, in Reading, Massachusetts, still has its presumably original cedar-shingled roof, which was standard at so many fast-food restaurants of the 1970s and even into the 1980s. Many mansards saw their roofs updated to other materials, and many were repainted red in later years.

This location has been on my radar since my friend, the diner expert Larry Cultrera, told me about it last year, and I went for a visit not long after. 

This is store No. 595, which would date this franchise to 1963 or so, which means there was an original “red and white” structure here in the early days. Presumably, the mansard followed in the 1970s, and now, and this can’t surprise anyone at this point, the third generation of design will soon be unveiled here. The operator has filed plans to demolish this location and replace it with a McBox.

Find out more about this location, and get much more retro travel news, in my latest newsletter, at the link in the bio. 🍔🍟 #retrologist

On June 6, 1933, 90 years ago today, the first drive-in movie theater flickered to life, in Camden, New Jersey. That’s why today is National Drive-in Movie Day.

By the summer of 1958, Americans had their choice of 4,038 cinemas under the stars. That summer proved to be the zenith. TVs, VCRs, Nintendos, Netflix: The next half-century of distractions helps explain the decline.

But drive-ins, they haven’t played their last reel, although those reels are more often than not digital files these days. In fact, the pandemic led to a resurgence, with pop-ups sprouting up to satisfy the quarantine-weary.

The United Drive-in Theatre Owners Association counts 302 drive-in theaters in the United States as of November 2022, down from 318 as of September 2021. There are a total of 533 screens in service, the group reports.

I’m blessed to live in a state, New York, with the most drive-in theaters, at 28. Alaska, Delaware, Hawaii, Louisiana, and North Dakota have none. (No surprise about Alaska!) The remaining 44 states have at least one.

Here are some of my favorites that I’ve photographed on the road over the years. Find out where they are, and see even more of them, in my latest newsletter at the link in my bio! #retrologist

In a stroke of marketing brilliance, McDonald’s is celebrating “Grimace’s Birthday” in a campaign that barely features Grimace himself, at least not in stores. He’s not on the cups, or the food containers, or in the posters. But for people who grew up with Grimace, you don’t need to see Grimace to be able to visualize him.

In my latest newsletter, at the link in the bio, I analyze the campaign and argue that “McDonald’s does not have to rebuild PlayPlaces with these characters or restore the mansard buildings they are relentlessly demolishing. The act of merely hinting at a vintage character’s existence (again, Grimace is hardly seen in this campaign) is sufficient to drive social conversation, sales and widen the circle — and lower the age — of people connected emotionally to the brand.”

So where can you actually see Grimace? Here are some of the restaurants, some no longer around, where you can see the big purple guy. Locations are in my newsletter – please sign up to follow my adventures.

Fun Grimace fact: The original 1971 version of Grimace was called “Evil Grimace” and had four arms to facilitate grabbing as many milkshakes as possible. He was perhaps too evil for impressionable children, and he soon lost his extra set of arms and became the lovable oaf we know and love today. #retrologist

Happy 104th birthday @awrestaurants! 

On June 20, 1919, a humble little root-beer stand opened on a hot day in Lodi, California. Roy W. Allen’s beverage, sold for a nickel a frosty mug, would become the foundation of the A&W root beer chain of restaurants.

Here are some other A&Ws, past and present, you might want to visit across America! Learn more and find out where these and other A&Ws are by visiting the link in my bio, and reading (and subscribing if you like) to my Retrologist newsletter! If you like what I post, the newsletter is made for you! #retrologist

It was 83 years ago today that the very first Dairy Queen opened at 501 N. Chicago St. in Joliet, Illinois.

The soft serve was called “Dairy Queen,” and the queen in question, the oft-cited story goes, was the ordinary cow, without which the product would not exist.

That first DQ was a sensation, and the young couple who managed the shop thought it was a “dream come true” – because soft serve does not require laborious hand-dipping, explains Naomi Mortensen in her book on the history of DQ.

From there, the chain would spread far and wide from its birthplace in the Land of Lincoln, and today numbers over 6,000 stores.

Of those locations, the special ones – the ones where the ice cream just hits better — are the legacy stores that have preserved a taste of the simple charms of the American roadside.

For a second year on this day, I am sharing a celebratory tour of some of my favorite DQs. 

First up is my favorite DQ photo, preserving a moment of snowy serenity one February day in Butler, Pennsylvania. The snow melted within an hour.

No. 2 keeps the snow theme going at the Dairy Queen in Anaconda, Montana.

Our third stop is the DQ in Iowa City, Iowa, whose sign is a meticulous recreation of the original one lost in a 2006 tornado.

No. 4 is a perfect DQ “Country Fresh” barn, gleaming in East Windsor, New Jersey.

No. 5 is a charming store in Salisbury, North Carolina, a state that has some of the nicest vintage DQs. (And yes, it says 1950 — that’s when this store opened, 10 years after DQ began.)

No. 6 is a Dairy Queen in Hackettstown, New Jersey, and No. 7 is a DQ in Huntington, West Virginia. I love that “sunroom meets spaceship” design!

No. 8 is a country barn charmer in Faribault, Minnesota, across from one of the A&Ws I showed you the other day!

No. 9 is a DQ set amid palm trees in New Smyrna Beach, Florida. The most significant change here since 1953 is the addition of hot dogs to the menu in 1983!

And finally, we end at the @dairyqueen in Wantage, New Jersey, and one of my favorite features of older shops – the lamp cones on the lawn!

Where’s your favorite Dairy Queen? #retrologist

It’s National Onion Day, and I figured I should post something with a peel! 🧅 

Sorry, I couldn’t resist! And you know what else I couldn’t resist? The Hungry Onion, in Meridian, Idaho.

I visited in February 2022 after they had closed for the season, and it turned out, alas, that they had closed for good.

The very next month, they announced they had gone out of business, pointing to inflation and the labor crunch as among the factors. They vowed in a Facebook post that they were scouting out a new, bigger home, saying the old roadside stand was no longer viable.

This was not the first time the Hungry Onion closed. They called it quits in late 2019, only to return amid the pandemic. 

If they reopen yet again, I can only hope they’ll keep this amazing sign. You can visit the Hungry Onion right now if you stream the 1980 Clint Eastwood movie “Bronco Billy.” Eastwood’s eponymous character, a stuntman fronting a traveling Wild West show, visits the roadside stand. (See an image from the film in the second slide. The Hungry Onion hadn’t changed all that much in four decades, except for the obligatory addition of a shingled mansard roof!)

The Bronco Billy burger remained a fixture on the stand’s “secret menu” until the end. 

According to the Idaho Statesman, Eastwood’s burger was a quarter pounder with bacon, cheese, and barbecue sauce served on a hoagie roll. 

You definitely wanted to get the onion rings on the side – the place was said to be named after them. And yes, there is a National Onion Ring Day, but we just missed the big day – it was on June 22. For the record, I’m always down to celebrate onion rings.

Tears and onions go together, and I wistfully point out that 2023 would have been the Hungry Onion’s 60th birthday. Maybe we’ll see its kind again one day in these parts, and, even if we don’t, we can always savor the memories. #retrologist

I couldn’t let National Camera Day pass by without dipping into my archive of photo shop pictures. And I quickly settled on sharing an old friend — Krauss Photo in Port Jervis, New York. 

Here’s my essay on this gem: 

Gus Krauss operated this beautiful photo store for much of the 20th century. After his death in 1977, he was praised for his pivotal role in chronicling this upstate city, and for the collection of postcards and photographic equipment he amassed. 

The facade is a masterpiece of retail beauty, and the @kodak sign (swipe for a look) was once a familiar sight in downtowns across the land. 

As I took these photos with my digital camera, I could almost smell the faint whiff of fixer wafting from behind the dusty drapes in the windows. It’s humbling to think how many memories were preserved because of the work of Mr. Krauss and his successors, Marion and Don Cole. 

Few folks get prints anymore — they’re content to have their priceless memories living on their soon-to-be-upgraded phones or in “the cloud” or right here on @instagram. But that doesn’t feel particularly tangible — it feels dangerously ephemeral. 

There is something very comforting about having prints, in an album, passed down by hand from generation to generation. 

Krauss Photo Service is a priceless snapshot of this lost time. #retrologist

The Chambersburg Mall: 1982-2023

At half a million square feet, this Pennsylvania mall was like a city, with four anchor stores, a movie theater and around 75 individual shops at its peak.

Today at 2, the final tenant — an antiques center that occupied the site of the former Sears — closed forever, and so ended the life of the Chambersburg Mall.

I paid my respects during a visit in April. Here’s part of what I wrote about my tour in my latest newsletter, accessible at the link in the bio: It was beautiful inside, in that the mall was lit only by natural light from its skylights, and they cast warm spotlights through the darkened corridors. The entrance to the defunct Bon-Ton, with a tall, healthy ficus tree and a prominently positioned wooden bench, was a lovely tableau, a dignified pose in the face of certain death.

There were the unmistakable scars of familiar retail denizens like Bath & Body Works. The wood-paneled facade with a row of green lamposts and the checkered awnings — a decidedly 1990s design — has become a totem of the dead mall, a sign that time has passed this place.

Near the entrance was the label scar for a former Bonanza steakhouse, emblazoned on delicious, perpendicularly arranged wood paneling. That location had left the dying mall and is now located nearby.

And that was it, my quick visit was over. I thought of trying to push deeper into the mall, but it was a little spooky and not a little sad. It’s a story, of course, that’s been playing out from coast to coast, a story that is far from over. We know why places like the Chambersburg Mall – which replaced farms and orchards – have failed, but the important question now is what should replace malls?

Join the conversation here or in the comments section of my newsletter, which I encourage you to subscribe to! #retrologist

Happy birthday, Mr. ZIP!

ZIP codes were first rolled out on July 1, 1963, 60 years ago this weekend.

The five-digit numbers, part of the ZIP — Zone Improvement Plan — were an organizational godsend for the then-named United States Post Office Department, helping the agency handle the avalanche of mail coursing through the system back in those decidedly analog days, where electronic communication was the stuff of “The Jetsons,” which had debuted on ABC the year before.

Large senders of mail as well as regular folks, however, wouldn’t immediately take to using ZIP codes, so they needed a nudge. Mr. ZIP, a jauntily drawn postman on the move, provided that nudge.

Mr. ZIP was retired decades ago, and is now a somewhat obscure figure in a Madison Avenue pantheon that includes Tony the Tiger, Poppin’ Fresh and the Keebler Elves. Unlike those other cartoon mascots, Mr. ZIP got served a pink slip, a victim perhaps of his own success.

Americans, you see, finally bought into ZIP codes, and the poor little fella had nothing left to do other than look adorable, so he was dispatched to Postal Service relic status like another speed-orientated icon of yore, the Pony Express.

But you can still find him on office-building mail chutes here and there, and even in some post offices – if you know where to look.

More about Mr. ZIP – including a video on his origins –  awaits you at the link in my bio, where you can read and subscribe to my Retrologist newsletter! #retrologist

Everything in life has an Alpha and an Omega, a beginning and an end.

Alpha Donuts’ beginning was in 1975, when coffee shops in New York City were as common as Starbucks are today, if not more so. Alpha’s Omega came last week when the beloved greasy spoon on Queens Boulevard in Sunnyside closed for good.

The longtime owner, Patty Zorbas, told the Long Island City Post that the Omega came not because of a rent hike — it wasn’t that bad, actually — but because of the residual damage inflicted by the pandemic.

So many shops managed to scrape by, but now, on the other side of the lockdowns, they are confronted with relentless problems like inflation and a shaky economy. When Zorbas realized she had to upgrade equipment like her grill — that which puts the grease in the spoon — she realized her heart was no match for her mind, which had done the math and concluded it was time to close.

All the wonderful things you see in these pictures — the rare S-shaped counter, the menu boards, the old-school cash register, the stools — are now gone. The space is a shell; the sign outside survives for now.

And what about the people who gave Alpha its heart?

Please visit the link in my bio to sign up for my newsletter and check out my full report – and tribute – to Alpha Donuts. #retrologist

Like a train on the move — a very slow-moving one — the Subway Inn is now on its third stop on a journey that began in 1937.

It sat for decades across Bloomingdale’s on East 60th, survived there until 2014, when it was pushed out for a development that still hasn’t happened, its original home now a sad, weed-choked lot. 

Then it was off to East 60th and Second Avenue, opening around the time the Second Avenue Subway was being built, so that seemed fortuitous. 

Well, real estate pressures forced it out if its second home, and now it’s settled in its latest home just up the street. 

Each time, they’ve taken along the iconic neon sign. That must be its lucky charm — and this is its third home. Third time’s the charm? 

Long may its neon sizzle!

Raise a glass tonight for the Subway Inn on this, National Dive Bar Day! #retrologist

I always thought the light brackets on the roofs of vintage mansard McDonald's were meant to represent french fries! I've also seen them in white, so perhaps not, but the very sight of the lights always gave me a hankering for Ronald's fries.

Today is National French Fry Day, and I couldn't let it pass without a reference to my favorite fries, the ones at McDonald's. They are a rare treat for me these days, and I resisted the urge to stop at my participating McDonald's for some free ones today!

This gorgeous location was in North Platte, Nebraska. It opened in 1978 and survived until 2018, an astonishing run, given that its interior was intact as well.

I share more about it, and my thoughts on a possible new future for the mansard design, in my latest newsletter, hot off the presses and at the link in my bio! #retrologist

With tens of thousands of storefronts spread across the five boroughs of New York City, the odds are in your favor that some of today’s bland awnings and uninspired signs are concealing historic gems.

In fact, it’s a guarantee that lurking all around us is a hidden museum of how New Yorkers once shopped.

Leapfrogging toward the top of my list of rediscovered treasures is the sign for Barney’s Shoes in Jackson Heights, Queens, which emerged from hiding above the entrance to what is now a Colombian restaurant, on 82nd Street near 37th Avenue.

The sign appears to be made of porcelain enamel and was once graced with neon tubing.

Before its long disappearance, it was photographed in the 1940s by a kindred spirit from another time, somebody whose photos I have long admired: Charles Phelps Cushing. His specialties included American Main Streets, and he captured an image of 82nd Street that features Barney’s Shoes and this exact sign. It gives me chills to think a sign Cushing photographed in the 1940s was photographed by me Saturday morning, and almost in the same spot, after being hidden for so long.

Up in my newsletter, I share my detective work on Barney’s, the stunning Cushing photo (which I only have the rights to use in connection with the newsletter) and classic newspaper ads featuring Barney’s Shoes, which is enjoying an unexpected comeback in another century.

This is a shoo-in for my favorite story - and find - of the year! #retrologist

The  Big Chicken of Marietta, Georgia, is celebrating his 60th anniversary this year! I finally scratched this roadside icon off my bucket list, although this KFC does not have a big bucket, but rather, well, a Big Chicken. The story goes Col. Harland Sanders was no fan of the big chicken. The 56-foot-tall bird survived a few more brushes with death, and is still standing. And thank goodness he is — how else would folks in town give directions? (Make a left at the Big Chicken!) I have the story — and much more — in my latest newsletter at the link in the bio!  #retrologist

It’s hard to believe “National Lampoon’s Vacation” just celebrated its 40th anniversary!

As a road-tip aficionado, this is one film I love watching, especially the opening sequence that features vintage postcards of classic roadside Americana! The montage – and Lindsey Buckingham’s “Holiday Road” – always put me in the mood to hit the road, hopefully without the complications the Griswolds encounter!

A number of those places featured in the open are still around, and here are five that I’ve been to and photographed over the years! I thought it would be fun to turn them into “postcards,” just like in the movie.
