I’m lovin’ it!

I enjoy visiting a McDonald’s that looks like a McDonald’s is supposed to, and this gem in Orange, Connecticut, fits the bill.

I absolutely adore the quirky carousel theme at this McDonald’s, too. It’s a vivid reminder of the days when McDonald’s stores could indulge in regional quirkiness. They weren’t all the same. Hardly.

With the success of Adult Happy Meals and the Grimace Birthday Shake, McDonald’s is now unmistakably aware that nostalgia translates to a McFlurry of profits.

So when the news broke recently that McDonald’s is considering new, smaller restaurants called CosMc, named after an obscure 1980s McDonaldland character who is a McDonald’s-obsessed robot alien, one has to ask: Will they now extend that nostalgia to the drafting boards of future architecture plans? Could CosMc save us from the McBox?

I have much more on that, plus lots of roadside Americana news, in my latest newsletter, which you can read – and subscribe to – in my story or at link in my bio!  #retrologist

It’s National Radio Day, so it’s as good a time as any to share three of my favorite buildings I’ve had the pleasure to photograph.

The first slide is the old KPRK transmitter building in Livingston, Montana; the second is the WMCA transmitter building, on a salt marsh in Kearny, New Jersey; and the third belongs to WPTF just outside Raleigh, North Carolina.

In my newsletter, at the link in my bio, I have essays on each of these places, along with some cool extras. To tweak the old saying of one of my favorite radio voices, Charles Osgood, “See you on the newsletter!”

I certainly still tune into AM radio – mainly for news – on my long drives. And I occasionally fiddle with the car’s tuner to find local stations and (hopefully) pick up some local atmosphere. But if podcasts are the descendants of traditional radio, then I listen to PLENTY of radio on my drives!

How about you? #retrologist

My travels over the past few days took me as far north as Springfield, Massachusetts and as far south and west as White Post, Virginia, where I visited the wonderful Dinosaur Land. (All shall be documented in my newsletter soon!)

Wherever I am, I’m always on the lookout for interesting fast food places, which, like those dinosaurs, are pretty prehistoric by today’s architectural standards, but, like those dinosaurs, are pretty cool, too. I visited several interesting spots, including a handful of throwback Burger King and McDonald’s locations, like the gem you see here.

This McDonald’s, rocking the relatively rare green mansard roof, is in Somerset, New Jersey, and I made a quick stop here on Sunday to check in on this old friend.

For the first time, I poked around inside and much to my delight, discovered a mirror featuring the frosted likeness of the big guy himself, the king of fast food clowns, Ronald McDonald. He’s standing on an island (or ironing board😄) joined by the Hamburger Patch, a Fry Kid and some ferns. In other words, it’s epic! 

Ronald may be all but gone from McDonald’s mainstream marketing these days, but it’s nice to know he’s holding court in this corner of McDonaldland.

For McDonald’s fans, I have exciting news: I’m working on a guide to some of my favorite McDonald’s buildings, PlayPlaces and signs in the nation. I hope to make it similar to my Pizza Hut and Maryland Fried Chicken guides. It will be dropping soon on my newsletter – and will be a work in progress with frequent updates –  so make sure you sign up at the link in my bio! #retrologist

So today is National Pecan Torte Day, NOT National Pecan Day, but you had me at pecans. I associate pecans with road trips and the baking of sweet memories.

A pecan torte isn't particularly convenient to consume while behind the wheel -- a pecan log roll, however, is! So you know that if there's a Stuckey's somewhere along the road ahead of me, and there are 65 licensed locations and 200 retailers carrying their goods, I'm stopping for pecan log rolls, or maple pecans, or pecan halves, or roasted and salted pecans -- you get the idea! Indeed, Stuckey's is the reason WHY I associate pecans with hitting the road.

To mark the day, I'm sharing a few pecan-related photos from my travels, starting with a former Horne's restaurant in Lawtey, Florida, where pecan candies were a specialty. (There's only one Horne's left, in Port Royal, Virginia.) The founder of Horne's, Bob Horne, first toiled in the kitchen of @stuckeystop in Eastman, Georgia, where a lovely mural commemorates the founding of this iconic roadside oasis and pioneer of the franchise concept, undergoing revival today in the expert and caring hands of Stephanie Stuckey.

Last December, while I was exploring the Southeast during Christmas week, she tipped me off to a wonderful Stuckey's location in Summerton, South Carolina, from which the next few pictures originate. @stuckeysofsummerton is an absolute gem, as you can see from the pictures, and comes complete with a Dairy Queen. Score!

I can't wait to hit the road again, and it’s all the better if there's a Stuckey's billboard off in the distance. #retrologist

If you have yet to succumb to the “Barbenheimer” experience — or are ready for another round — Sunday might be the most economically advantageous day to catch these or many other movies at a theater near you. That’s because Sunday is National Cinema Day, and theaters participating in the promotion will be selling tickets for $4. Those prices are straight out of the mid-1980s.

Last Saturday night, I could have watched “Barbie” or “Oppenheimer” at full price at the Senator Theatre in Baltimore, but the feature presentation for me was outside and free — the fabulous Art Deco facade at twilight. (Alas, the facade was not fully lit, but I was still dazzled.)

I’d been looking to visit this one for years, and it’s cool I got to do it with these two instantly iconic movies emblazoned on the marquee. The Senator screened its first film in 1939, and through its almost 84 years has seen its share of happy endings, dramatic twists, and nail-biting cliffhangers, both on and off the screen.

The biggest cliffhanger perhaps came in 2009, when the theater closed, foiled by foreclosure. But the Senator never became a forlorn husk, a beautiful ruin, as so many of its architectural brethren have coast to coast. The people of Baltimore wouldn’t stand for it, and the city itself saved the damsel in distress by buying the Senator and getting it into the caring hands of the Cusack family. Sure there were a few more bumps on the journey to the gem you see today, but those bumps are in the rear-view mirror.

Today, the sumptuously renovated and expanded Senator boasts three screens, including the grand 40-foot silver one in the main auditorium. State-of-the-art digital projection is the usual method of movie-magic delivery. But not always. The theater is still equipped with its 35-millimeter film projection suite, so classic movies can be seen as they were in their heyday.

Those projectors were put back to work one glorious night in October 2013, when the theater reopened after its multimillion-dollar makeover. 

All it needed for the big bash was some “Hairspray,” and beloved Baltimore native John Waters obliged, screening his 1988 film for a crowd of hundreds. #retrologist

Aug. 24 celebrates waffles (National Waffle Day) and peaches (National Peach Pie Day).

The perfect place to celebrate both holidays is Interstate 85 in Gaffney, South Carolina, where the Peachoid and Mr. Waffle are about a 10-minute drive apart. 

Let’s start with the Peachoid! It’s a 135-foot-tall water tower that’s shaped like a giant peach. The peach business is big in these parts, and the Peachoid, which holds a million gallons of water, won’t let you forget it.

It was constructed in 1981 and became an instant tourist draw and symbol of this city and the peach industry around here. (Georgia may be known for its peaches, but South Carolina grows more of them.)

The Peachoid instantly drew oohs, aahs, and, of course, snorts, with cheeky nicknames like “The Moon Over Gaffney.” It even figured in a plot line in the show “House of Cards.” In the episode, the Peachoid so distracts a motorist she dies in a car accident. Kids will see a huge emoji in the sky. 🍑 

From the Peachoid, it’s not much of a drive to Mr. Waffle, a restaurant that has been serving up the breakfast delicacy since 1975.

Maybe they’ll serve you a slice of peach pie after wolfing down your 🧇 to complete your experience. #retrologist

You’re in the doghouse now!

Normally, that’s a bad thing. As Brenda Lee famously crooned, “you’ve worn out your welcome mat.” Pack your bags, buddy.

But things are looking up if you’re in this doghouse – Charlie’s Dog House Diner in Cleveland, Ohio.

The business, which also goes by Charlie’s Restaurant, is one of the cutest buildings I’ve ever visited. This is actually an old Valentine diner that has been expanded and modified, supplied with a charming dog-house facade, complete with two pooches standing sentinel.

The Kansas Historical Society, which tracks these old diners, explains this was the first location of the regional Dog House chain in 1952, and it’s still here, on 2102 Brookpark Road, where Cleveland meets Parma.

When I stopped by last year, it had closed up for the day, but I took a look through the window. So cute. 

The local paper recently touted Charlie’s Cleveland dog – Vienna beef, topped with stadium mustard and chopped onions, pointing out that while the Dog House is small on space, it’s big on nostalgic charm.

I salute Charlie’s Dog House Diner on this, National Dog Day! #retrologist

Saturday night at dusk, I found myself outside this vintage Dairy Queen, so I dutifully pulled over for a few shots. This “Country Fresh” barn — a design introduced in the early 1960s — is my second favorite of the DQ buildings, after the original small white buildings with the projecting neon signs.

One thing that’s neat about this one is that it’s not in the country, as the design might imply, but a mere five miles from the George Washington Bridge and 13 miles from the Empire State Building. But it might as well be a world away. It sure feels that way. 

Find this DQ at 260 Teaneck Road in Teaneck, New Jersey. #retrologist

You’ll “Marvel” at this retro dining room.

Visitors to the @mcdonalds at 6620 Bay Parkway in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, are getting a well-deserved break today through Friday, Sept. 1, stepping into a McDonald’s straight out of 1982.

The immersive throwback experience is a collaboration between McDonald’s and Marvel Studios ahead of the second season of “Loki,” streaming Oct. 6 on Disney+.

The character of Sylvie travels to 1982, and ends up working at a McDonald’s.

Every corner of the dining room has old-school touches that will amuse those of us who experienced 1982, and give those born later in “the timeline” a taste of what they missed.

See full story, more photos and video at the link in my bio! #retrologist

If Pizza Hut implies a small building with a pointy roof, then what have we here? The Pizza Closet?

Make yourself at home – if you can find any space to – at the Littlest Pizza Hut, located at West 55th Street and Eighth Avenue in Manhattan. It took some creative doing to fit a Pizza Hut into this slender slice of Manhattan real estate, but this Pizza Hut is all kitchen, no dining room. It’s for takeout only, and most of the people stuffed in here like cheese in a Pizza Hut crust are delivery workers, ferrying pies to apartment dwellers nearby.

For a space so little, it’s big on details that mean a lot. They’ve installed classic Pizza Hut lamps over the counter, and the walls are dotted with posters for things like Book It.

Sure, there are no red plastic cups, gingham tablecloths, salad bars, arcade games and well, big red roofs. But that’s OK – the Littlest Pizza Hut gets an A for effort.

Nobody Outpizzas The Hut, the copywriters say, but this is New York City, where every pizzeria is trying to outpizza every other, and the big winners are those of us privileged enough to feast on it all.

No, the Littlest Pizza Hut is not a New York slice joint, nor is it trying to be. It’s just trying to make it in the Big City, just like everyone else.

***

If you want to visit a real Pizza Hut Classic — vintage buildings “retro renovated” to look like they did in their nostalgic heyday — head up to the link in my bio and find one near you in my #retrologist newsletter roundup, which is regularly updated with new spots. And don’t forget to hit subscribe while you’re there!

On Saturday, Jan. 20, 1973, the grand opening of the McDonald’s at the Dalewood Shopping Plaza in Hartsdale, New York, was heralded in a full-page ad in the local newspaper.

The very next day, Jan. 21, 1973, I was born a few towns over, and sometime in the next year or so, it was here, at the McDonald’s at 407 N. Central Ave., that I had my first taste of McDonald’s, according to my parents. This was my family’s go-to Golden Arches until the mansard (now McBox) opened in Tarrytown, New York, a few years later.

So I’ve always held a soft spot for the Hartsdale store, which remained a nostalgic oasis, one of the nicest unrenovated locations.

@retailpocalypse reported on Friday, much to my dismay, that this place has been gutted, and so goes with it another piece of my childhood. 

My full tribute to this old-school McDonald's can be read at the link in my bio in my newsletter. Please subscribe! #retrologist

The ultimate Blue Light Special happens when a Kmart store puts everything up for sale, right down to the Blue Light itself, as it prepares to turn off the fluorescents forever and go out of business.

That’s the sad story at the last Kmart in New Jersey, closing on the eve of its 41st birthday. In fact, once this Kmart is gone, there will only be two left in the continental United States — one in Miami, Florida, and another in Bridgehampton, on New York’s Long Island.

Up in my newsletter — read and subscribe at the link in the bio -- I take you around this store for a farewell tour, and share the story of Kmart and how it went from everywhere to nowhere in what seems like a blink of an eye.

Did you shop at Kmart? #retrologist

I first wrote a variant of this piece back in September 2011, on the occasion of the 10th anniversary of 9/11. I’ve shared it every year since, as a tribute to the people we lost that awful day.

***

The Twin Towers, toward the end of their short time on the skyline, had arguably become the definitive symbol of New York City. They were destroyed 22 years ago today. Six years from now, they will have been gone as long as they stood.

The towers were destroyed in the city’s worst 102 minutes, but their iconographic legacy has proven remarkably resilient.

These images of the Twin Towers — a neon window silhouette here, a graphic on a delivery truck there — can be considered collectively as a quiet yet powerful citywide memorial to the people we lost.

I’ve long been collecting images of the Twin Towers that still survived in New York City. Many of these signs are now long gone, as well.

I don’t spot many these days. Still, it’s my tradition to share them here with you, every Sept. 11. They were once shorthand for New York City — simple signs. Now, they represent so much more. #neverforget

I drove to New Hampshire to hit the slopes. This is not unusual behavior, but the slopes of which I speak weren’t on a snow-covered mountain.

They were under a mansard-covered McDonald’s.

A reviewer on Yelp calls the McDonald’s in Conway, New Hampshire, “the most magical place in New England,” and for the enthusiast of “nonstandard McDonald’s,” this is hardly hyperbole.

Well, you know this is coming: I arrived at the McDonald’s after it had been closed for remodeling, but it still stood intact, so I was able to catch a glimpse of the wonders before they vanished.

The dining room has a remarkable ski-resort motif, with ski gondola and lift chairs turned into seating. I was definitely lovin’ it. I hope that, once the remodeling is done, the ski motif will be preserved.

My recent road trip through New England was full of fun fast-food finds like this. Up in my latest newsletter – link in my bio – I have the rundown on the Conway restaurant and many other must-see spots.

I also visited a McDonald’s in a mansion, a Burger King with a cozy fireplace and many more spots you might find interesting.

What’s the quirkiest McDonald’s you’ve ever visited? #retrologist

Today's the last day of summer 2023. It also happens to be National Ice Cream Cone Day, a reminder to get your last licks in of summer fun!

To salute both occasions, I present a gem from my recent trip through New England -- Caddy's Ice Cream Shack in Cumberland Center, Maine.

Caddy's has all the elements of a classic roadside ice cream stand, but it's only 10 years old. And who doesn't love the repurposed Big Boy statue proudly displaying an ice cream cone instead of his signature hamburger. 

Caddy's is a reminder that something new can still be something true -- and something cool!

I hope you got to enjoy some fun road trips this summer. I can't wait to start my autumn drives, as my favorite time of year arrives! 🍁 🎃 Stay tuned for updates, here and in my newsletter! #retrologist

An early 1990s slogan for McDonald’s was “what you want is what you get, at McDonald’s today.” The same can be said for McDonald’s itself.

When the Golden Arches wanted to move into Freeport, Maine, the hometown of L.L. Bean and a bastion of Colonial-style architecture, the townsfolk blanched. Even though the common style of McDonald’s in 1984 — the mansard — was designed to blend better into suburban communities, McDonald’s was going to have to do better to become a neighbor of L.L. Bean.

But McDonald’s gets what it wants! They bought the Gore House, built by well-heeled merchant William Gore around 1850, and opened a restaurant there in December 1984, garnering national headlines.

Even if you’re a hungry driver searching for a McDonald’s, you would scarcely notice its presence. The building is attractive in an unostentatious way, respectably blending into the traditional streetscape, just like the folks in Freeport wanted. I even made some friends there, who told me some of this history. 

Learn more, see more pictures and visit more old-school and cool fast-food places with me by reading (and subscribing) to my newsletter at the link in my bio. #retrologist

Today is Jimmy Carter’s 99th birthday, and to mark the milestone, I’ve put together a special tour of his hometown of Plains, Georgia, which you can read at the link in my bio.

So much of Plains, Georgia, is built around the image of two things: @jimmycarternps and peanuts. Indeed, at the Smiling Peanut statue on the edge of this small city, a peanut and Carter’s toothy grin are forever fused, much like peanuts and Carter are in the public mind.

This town in southwestern Georgia pays homage to the peanut farmer who became president, only to return to the land that he cultivated — and that cultivated him, where he is much loved and today is celebrating his birthday at the modest ranch house that he built for himself and his beloved wife, Rosalynn, in 1961.

Please read – and subscribe – to my newsletter at the link in my bio! #retrologist #jimmycarter99 #jimmycarter

Seventy-three years today, the world was first introduced to “Peanuts.”

Well, it wasn’t the world, just seven newspapers that took a chance on Charle M. Schulz’s comic strip on Oct. 2, 1950. 

Long before we called instant success going viral, “Peanuts” did just that, and the world would soon know — and love — these wonderful characters and their all-too-human foibles.

Head up to the link in the bio for my full list, photos and maps on how to visit these places where you can celebrate the heritage of “Peanuts.” The places include:

2.) Snoopy’s Doghouse, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 

3.) Warm Puppy Cafe, Santa Rosa, California (at Charles M. Schulz Museum)

4.) Table forever reserved for Mr. Schulz at the Warm Puppy Cafe

5.) Peanuts crossing, Santa Rosa, California (outside cafe) 

6.) Ad for Warm Puppy Cafe, Coddingtown Shopping Center, Santa Rosa, California

At the Burger King in North Conway, New Hampshire, you really are treated like a king.

Rare is the fast-food chain restaurant that has a stylish sunken dining area complete with – wait for it – a modernist fireplace! You can enjoy your flame-broiled Whopper by this cozy fireplace on a chilly New England day. This is about as good as it gets – as far as fast-food dining environments go, that is.

This beauty is just down the road from the ski-lodge McDonald’s that I profiled here recently, and that, sadly, has closed for a remodel.

The closure of that McDonald’s apparently boosted business at this Burger King, but I guess you can have too much of a good thing, if you go by the sign the BK posted in its drive-thru asking customers for patience as workers coped with the added demand.

Much to my frustration, the Burger King’s dining room was closed on the day I visited, so this was the best shot I was able to get of the fireplace — a window shot. This place definitely deserves a return visit.

Other fast-food chains have dabbled in fiery design features – Taco Bell back in the day used to have fire pits outside. A&W – admittedly less fast-food place than a family restaurant – featured restaurants with central fireplaces surrounded by counter seating, and some do remain, @roadarch_com tells us.

Want to see more? It’s easy! Head up to the link in my bio, check out my New England fast-food tour, and subscribe to my newsletter to keep stories like this coming straight to your inbox! (It’s a great way to support what I do, if you are a fan.)

Today is the 75th anniversary of @innout Burger!

The first In-N-Out opened in Baldwin Park, California, on Oct. 22, 1948, at 4:15 p.m. to be precise.

1948 was a pivotal year in the history of American fast food. As Harry and Esther Synder were opening their In-N-Out in Baldwin Park, the McDonald brothers in San Bernardino were converting their 8-year-old restaurant into a self-service, drive-in affair, a big step in the journey toward McDonald’s as we know it.

The year before, Fatburger had opened in Los Angeles. Carl’s Jr. was already around, and serving hamburgers since 1946, and Jack in the Box was three years away from springing to life.

The story of how America ate at midcentury and beyond was incubating in Southern California.

This store you see here is the closest you can get to that early In-N-Out experience, because the original is long gone, demolished for the construction of Interstate 10. So it’s appropriate that it was the 10 that brought me here two years ago today. (By coincidence, I visited on the chain’s anniversary.)

A retro store has just opened in Las Vegas, and in Pomona, California, today, an anniversary celebration is underway. See more pictures and get more information by visiting the link in the bio to read my latest newsletter. And please sign up if you haven’t! #retrologist

Pepsi-Cola turns 125 this year, and is celebrating the milestone with a new logo that draws inspiration from the beloved 1970s Globe. For the first time in 32 years, the word Pepsi is centered in the negative space of the Globe. (Swipe to the last slide.)

It’s crystal that @pepsi is asserting its heritage again, finding what’s iconic and enduring about its imagery, joining brands like Burger King and Pizza Hut in embracing their iconograhic legacy, and taking a page from Coca-Cola, which has always knows never to mess too much with its “Real Thing.”

And that discovery of its heritage led to the pop-up Pepsi 125 Diner, open in Manhattan through Oct. 29. Even if you don’t spring for the $50 meal, you can enjoy the  gorgeous sign of the new logo in the window. The rebrand is a sure sign that Pepsi has finally cleaned up 30 years of messing with its own, um, “Real Thing” — the classic Globe.

After 125 years in business, maybe they’ll realize that being the choice of a new generation doesn’t require changing your logo every few years.

I have written a really comprehensive post on the evolution of Pepsi’s logo, complete with fascinating details and more photos from my journeys, and I hope you’ll read it by visiting the link in my bio and supporting my work by subscribing!

Have a Pepsi Day, everyone! #retrologist

Salem, Massachusetts, is the so-called "Witch City." Sleepy Hollow, New York, is the hilly home of the Headless Horseman. And Westfield, New Jersey, has become the playground of the creepy, spooky and altogether kooky "Addams Family."

For the sixth year in a row, the birthplace of cartoonist Charles Addams, the creator of the beloved "Addams Family," has turned this charming suburban town into an immersive celebration called "AddamsFest."

These streets were a wellspring for Addams' imagination as a child in the early 20th century, and influenced his most famous creation.

Every day on his walk to school along Elm Street, the young Addams passed a haunting Victorian mansion that helped shape his depiction of his iconic "Addams Family" house. 

The young Addams frolicked amid the Colonial-era gravestones in the Presbyterian Church's burial ground, where lantern tours are offered during @addamsfest.

The Rialto Theater on East Broad Street appeared in his classic cartoons in the New Yorker magazine, where Addams freelanced for decades, first publishing an "Addams Family" panel in 1938.

The characters did not have names in his cartoons, but they made Addams, who signed them "Chas Addams," a household name.
It wasn't until the cartoons were being retooled for the beloved 1964-66 ABC-TV sitcom that Addams christened his characters, including matriarch Morticia, patriarch Gomez, Uncle Fester, and children Pugsley, and, of course, Wednesday. The sitcom plays in reruns to this day, and has spawned a cottage industry of movies and most recently, the Netflix series "Wednesday."

Indeed, it's been said that every day in Westfield is "Wednesday," and "AddamsFest" is the biggest sign of that.

"AddamsFest" is an ambitious volunteer effort that was the brainchild of Councilwoman Dawn Mackey, the chair of the @downtown_westfield celebration.

Mackey took me and my @abc7ny @localish colleague @marklnunez on a tour of the town, and you can see the fruits of our visit by visiting the link in my bio, where I’ve put together a guide to help you plan your own visit! 👻 #retrologist

Westfield, New Jersey, has become the playground of the creepy, spooky and all-together kooky “Addams Family.” 🎃

Follow @localish and @rolandopujol for more!

You’d think National Candy Day would fall on Halloween, but maybe that’s just a tad obvious. And hey, it wouldn't give the ghosts, ghouls and goblins their due.

So instead, we celebrate the occasion on Saturday, Nov. 4.

For many of us, every day is National Candy Day, and that can certainly be said for the shops profiled here.

So, my friends, let’s visit 10 shops where candy is the coin of the realm.

We’ll march east across the nation on an idiosyncratic tour, beginning with the Dale Country Store, one of my favorite spots in Oregon. Candy is among the sweet offerings here.

From there, we head to the Cactus Candy Company in Phoenix, Arizona, and its friendly if prickly mascot.

Next, let’s admire some Midwest neon at Lagomarcino’s in Moline, Illinois and Margie’s Candies’ in Chicago.

We find ourselves next in the Lehigh Valley, visiting Easton, Pennsylvania’s iconic Carmelcorn Shop.

We dart to the Jersey Shore, where more gooey goodness awaits us at the Caramel Shop in Ocean Township.

We pay tribute to a briefly resurfaced sign in Jersey City, a retail relic that’s no longer on display. Things do go better with Coke. 

We do some traveling through time in Manhattan, to Raul’s Candy Shop (closed) and Ray’s Candy Store (very much open.)

And finally, let’s admire Rocky Kandy & Grocery, a delicious Queens storefront with competing spellings of the word candy. (I’m team Kandy here.) along other typographic gems like “news paper,” “films,” and so on. Rocky’s is the champ of storefront kwirk – ehhr, quirk! #retrologist

Happy Sunday! Hope you enjoyed your “extra hour of sleep” as most of the nation returns to standard time. (Arizona and Hawaii avoid the biannual clock craziness and just stay on standard time.) You can reward yourself by having a donut, because fall-back day happens to fall on Nov. 5, which is National Doughnut Day!

If it seems like we just celebrated National Donut Day – note the different spelling –  it’s because we did. There are two on the books – the first one happens on the first Friday in June. That holiday was created in 1938 by the Salvation Army, a nod to the “doughnut lassies” who were dispatched to the front lines of World War I in France two decades earlier to support the soldiers, or “doughboys.” The lassies whipped up donuts, a welcome taste of home for the boys "over there." Their metal helmets were said to be perfect for making donuts in a pinch. It's a sweet story, and the Salvation Army uses the holiday as a fundraising opportunity each year.

The origins of the second celebration -- spelled National Doughnut Day -- are murky. The folks at Mental Floss got curious, too, and learned there may also be a veterans’ connection. Food-holiday historian John Bryan Hopkins found traces of the November celebration as far back as the 1930s, Mental Floss explains, and the Nov. 5 date, so close to Veterans Day, suggests it was also meant as a salute, perhaps by a business, to honor the “doughboys” who had served in World War I.

At any rate, I present what I think is the sweetest sign for the occasion, blending clocks and donuts – Donut Time in Oakland, California. The business, actually called Donut Corner, is long gone, but the sign, though it no longer keeps time, marches on. #retrologist

I’m having it my way at this Burger King.

I spotted this location recently on a drive through Westchester County, New York, and I knew I had to pull over.

The new retro logo, inspired by the 1969 classic, is becoming common enough now that I no longer totally lose it behind the wheel when I spot one. But boy, it sure looked nice here with this golden-hour glow.

I love how the franchise here, in Mount Kisco, has gone all-in on retro BK. Outside, the logo has been slapped on those pebble-covered trash cans, themselves old-school. The round sign enclosure that once held the swoosh logo now displays the square burger.

Inside, for the connoisseur of American roadside iconography, you’ll find treats that don’t require ordering anything from the menu. (Though, since you’re here, you might as well go for the onion rings.)

The actual 1969 logo can be found by the front door, beside a vintage picture of an old Burger King. The glass window separating the dining room from the operating play area features a depiction of The King from the 1960s, a pre-1969 Burger King logo.

The Parkette Drive-in will always be one that got away, for me anyway. 

This mainstay of Lexington, Kentucky, closed last year after 71 years. Business was not good, and the folks running it wanted out of their lease. Nobody else wanted to continue a business that was deemed no longer “viable.”

When I stopped by last month, there was no trace of the drive-in except the sign, and thank goodness we still have it. 

The city, recognizing its value as a roadside icon, has committed to keeping it just where it’s been all these years. You are looking at an official Lexington landmark now, and a plaque commemorating it could be coming along. 

And maybe even a cookbook with some of the recipes that made this place so popular, said Bryan Tipton, son-in-law of the Parkette’s founder, in an interview with TV station Lex18. 

The family still owns the land, and when I visited, it was being prepared to hold Lexus vehicles from the dealership next door. 

In a manner of speaking, it’s still a drive-in, hosting luxury cars now. 

But the greatest luxury will always be the iconic sign, which is reportedly being restored. 

“It was a really big deal, it was an important thing we thought we could do to save the Parkette name for many generations,” Tipton told Lex18.  #retrologist

It’s been well over a year since I posted my list of Pizza Hut Classics around the country, and I’ve kept adding locations ever since, now numbering over 60!

If you’ve never seen my list, head to the link in my bio or just Google “Pizza Hut Classics.” It’s the first thing that should come up.

I’m often asked what exactly makes a @pizzahut Classic. Is it any old-school Pizza Hut with the red pitched roof?

Not quite. 

Some folks, when stumbling upon a Pizza Hut Classic, think they’ve discovered a Pizza Hut that time forgot, that has never been updated since the 1980s.

Actually, Pizza Hut Classics are old-school locations that have been “retro renovated,” meaning they’ve been restored to a version of what they looked like decades ago. It’s the best thing happening in chain-restaurant design today. Rather than trash the past, Pizza Hut is not only embracing it, it’s re-creating it!

Here is the formula that goes into a Pizza Hut Classic:

1. The old 1974 logo (brought back in 2019) is used in pole signage as well as at the top of the (usually but not always) red-roofed restaurant. The pole sign features the addition of the word “Classic.”
2. The interior features cozy red booths and old-school Pizza Hut lamps.
3. Stickers featuring the long-discarded character Pizza Hut Pete are found on the door.
4. Posters feature classic photos from Pizza Huts of yore.
5. A plaque displays a quote from Pizza Hut co-founder Dan Carney, explaining the concept as a celebration of the brand’s heritage.

Of the dozens I have on my list, I’ve only visited a handful. These photos are from a mix of locations around the country. 

Have you been to a Pizza Hut Classic? What did you think? I’m overdue for another visit soon. I’ll just have to check my list. 👀 🍕 #retrologist

“The Great Christmas Light Fight” TV show needs more neon and classic signage, I say, and the show’s producers need look no farther than Jeff Rocklein’s house at 143 Rowland St. in Patchogue, New York.

For 13 years now, Jeff has been creating Christmas magic outside his Long Island home, and each year, the display has become a little more dazzling.

It all began in 2010, when Jeff placed a neon Christmas wreath outside his house. He’d fabricated it while taking a glass-blowing class at Brooklyn Glass in Park Slope.

“And that was the catalyst. I was like, ‘Oh, man, I can cover this house with neon,’” Jeff told me.

And so it began.

Jeff loves roadside Americana, and is around signs for a living. He’s a sign electrician, installing them, maintaining them, and, particularly relevant here, taking them down when businesses close or decide to take a new design direction.

The last step for these signs is usually the trash, but not when Jeff is around. (His colleagues in the business give him a little ribbing for his Dumpster-diving ways, but he’s also enlisted them in his search.) For years, he’s been salvaging what he can — colorful tubing, letters, light bulbs,
metal, you name it.

He always knew there was something creative he could do with this motley collection — other than sit in carton boxes in the basement.

Then it came, the flash of inspiration, the light-bulb moment. It occured to Jeff that he could turn all that design detritus into holiday light displays at his house, and thus was born the Neon Christmas House, which you can visit on @neonchristmashouse if you can’t make it out in person.

I invite you to visit the link in my bio to read the full story of how Jeff salvaged these signs and created such a magical display.

Merry Christmas from The Retrologist!

Toys R Us, at least as we knew it for decades, went out of business in the United States back in 2018. 

The U.S. branch of the brand, in new hands, is now in its second comeback attempt, affiliating itself with hundreds of Macy’s stores and operating two standalone flagship stores, one at the American Dream Mall in East Rutherford, New Jersey, and a second at the Mall of America in Bloomington, Minnesota.

And though it will soon be almost six years since the chain collapsed in the United States, there are still ghosts of it haunting the retail landscape.

This is one of them — a former Toys R Us in Wayne, New Jersey, its vintage signage still standing. I found a little sticker in the window featuring Geoffrey, announcing the store is protected by the “Toys ‘R’ Us Electronic Alarm Network.”

The more recent Toys R Us logo can also be found over what was the front entrance. Want to see more TRU remnants? Head up to the link in my bio to visit three other former New York area stores with traces of old-school Toys R Us.

Wayne used to be the heart of Toys R Us country. Its headquarters were down the road from here. The street name still survives — Geoffrey Way. #retrologist

About 90 minutes northeast of Houston, in the historic oil-boom town of Beaumont, lies the equivalent –  for me anyway –  of striking oil.

My spindletop, if you will, can be found in the Parkdale Mall, where one of two remaining exclusively Suncoast Motion Picture Company stores is still putting on a show for shoppers – and stopping nostalgists like me cold in their tracks.

Unlike the one that survives in Jacksonville, North Carolina, which I’ve also visited, this store still sports its neon sign. Inside, it hardly resembles the Suncoasts of yore – long gone are the racks upon racks of VHS tapes and movie memorabilia.

Yet somehow, the sun has not yet set on this Suncoast. There used to be hundreds at the chain’s peak. Musicland – remember them? – once owned Suncoast, then Best Buy bought Musicland in early 2000s, and their business instincts were right – right about 10 years too late. Worst Buy is more like it. They soon unloaded Suncoast and slowly the chain atrophied to just about nothing.

Suncoast’s light – at least its corporate heritage – still shines through FYE stores, which survive in more prodigious numbers.

But Suncoast is mostly a memory, heaped in with names like Blockbuster and Hollywood Video as names that define a different decade. 

Read my full story – and see more photos – at the Suncoast link in my bio. (Or DM me and I’lll send you the article!) #retrologist

The old jingle went, “In the land of Dairy Queen, we treat you right.”

That’s what they’ve been doing here since Sept. 11, 1949, when this Dairy Queen in Bemidji, Minnesota, opened. This barn design came along a couple of decades later, hailing from the “Country Fresh” look first rolled out in the early 1960s. 

Another reminder of that era is the small sign in the window featuring Little Miss Dairy Queen, who once topped so many of these red barn DQs as part of a weathervane.

This cute-as-a-button DQ is right down the road from one of the most famous — and one of my favorite — pieces of roadside Americana: Paul Bunyan and Babe the Blue Ox. If you watched “National Lampoon’s Vacation” over the holidays, you saw this attraction featured in the postcards that appear in the open credits as the song “Holiday Road” plays. 

This DQ is closed for the season, but I hope you get to visit one of these days, and explore this beautiful part of Minnesota. #retrologist

M&Ms melt in your mouth, not in your hands, and starting tonight, they will also kick off the new year in one sweet New Jersey town.

A candy factory in Hackettstown, New Jersey, has been making @mmschocolate since 1958, something that I did not know about until this week, and I make it my business to know this kind of arcana.

While Hackettstown is not quite at the level of Hershey, Pennsylvania, in embracing its candy-making heritage, it’s taking a big step tonight toward doing just that. That’s because a giant fiberglass M&M, studded with blingy lights, will be lowered at midnight in the heart of downtown here to ring in 2024.

I was captivated the minute I heard about these plans. So curious was I that I drove out to Hackettstown today for a quick look-see and was pleased by the sweet things I saw.

Check out my newsletter — with a full writeup on the M&M New Year’s Eve celebration and more photos — at the link in bio, and subscribe while you’re there!

The holidays are a time of culinary indulgence, and Jan. 2, the day so many hit the gym with renewed resolve after said indulgence, I find it interesting that we celebrate National Buffet Day, an event that would seem to encourage, well, indulgence.

I’m a child of the 1970s and 1980s, when the American road offered an endless bounty of buffet, from Sizzler (my family’s favorite, every Tuesday night for years!) to Bonanza and Ponderosa, both inspired by the TV show “Bonanza” and for decades under shared corporate ownership.

On this National Buffet Day, I was inspired to share some photos I took not long ago of the Ponderosa in Wisconsin Dells. No, I didn’t hit the buffet, but the feast for me was visual – simply seeing an open Ponderosa was the treat. Wisconsin Dells is a delightful time warp, so where better for a Ponderosa to defy the onslaught of Olive Gardens, Golden Corrals and Ruby Tuesdays?

This Ponderosa opened July 31, 1996, according to a clipping from the Baraboo News Republic, with seating for 350 along with a banquet room that could seat up to 110. And, yes, there was a buffet. You could enjoy a “Pondo-Combo’d” with buffet and sundae bar along with your hearty serving of beef.

There were about 600 Ponderoras in business when this location opened. Reportedly, a lucky 13 remain, making this location truly special, where it was once commonplace. (The fate of Bonanza is even bleaker – reportedly only three are left!)

Did you ever dine at Pondersosa or Bonanza? What are your memories? #retrologist

I was hopelessly smitten when I first visited Pea Soup Andersen’s in Buellton, California. The restaurant, founded by Anton and Juliette Andersen in 1924, was for 100 years a beloved part of the life and lore of the central California coast.

Yes, was.

Today, Jan. 10, 2024, Pea Soup Andersen’s abruptly closed.

I dreaded this moment. We all did, those who loved this place, even if we didn’t all hold the namesake pea soup in the highest esteem, even if 2 million bowls were ladled yearly, as the story went.

Because it was never really about the soup: It was about everything else about Andersen’s, this fantastically kitschy wonderous piece of roadside Americana.

Reports have evolved through the day, from total mystery about what happened to a story in a local newspaper indicating the site is in escrow, and a new owner aims to redevelop the property, with the building razed (the owner reportedly says it’s in hopelessly poor repair) and questions about whether it will even remain Pea Soup Andersen’s in its new iteration.

My goodness, I hope the charm of this place is preserved. I have much more in my newsletter, which you can read and subscribe to at the link in my bio. #retrologist
